question.title: Will Biden drop out before July 20?
question.body: If Biden drops out or is otherwise unable to continue the race before July 20 midnight Eastern Time, this market will resolve to yes. Otherwise, this market will resolve to no.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, President Joe Biden is actively campaigning for re-election in the 2024 United States presidential election. At that time, there were no indications that he planned to drop out of the race before July 20, 2024. Several factors can influence the likelihood of a candidate dropping out: 1. Health Concerns: President Biden would be 81 years old by July 2024. While age can bring increased health risks, there have been no public reports of significant health issues that would impede his ability to campaign or serve. The statistical probability of mortality or severe health incapacitation for someone of his age within a year is relatively low, though not negligible. 2. Political Pressure: Unless there is a significant shift in political support, such as a major scandal, drastic drop in approval ratings, or strong opposition within his own party, it's unlikely that he would face pressure to withdraw. As of October 2023, he maintains substantial support within the Democratic Party. 3. Personal Decision: While unforeseen personal reasons could lead to a candidate withdrawing, there's no information suggesting President Biden is considering this. 4. Historical Precedence: Incumbent presidents running for re-election rarely drop out of the race unless faced with significant challenges. The last incumbent president not to seek re-election was Lyndon B. Johnson in 1968, under unique circumstances. Considering these factors, while there is always some level of uncertainty due to potential health issues or unexpected events, the probability of President Biden dropping out before July 20, 2024, is low.

question.title: Will Will Hurd be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Will Hurd is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of October 2023, the race for the Republican nomination for the 2024 US Presidential Election is heavily dominated by high-profile candidates such as former President Donald Trump and Florida Governor Ron DeSantis. Polls consistently show these candidates leading by significant margins nationally and in key primary states. Will Hurd, a former U.S. Representative from Texas, announced his candidacy in June 2023 but has struggled to gain traction. His name recognition is low compared to the frontrunners, and he has not secured substantial fundraising or endorsements.

Furthermore, Hurd's moderate stances on certain issues may not align with the current Republican primary electorate, which tends to favor more conservative candidates. Historical data indicates that candidates polling below 1-2% at this stage rarely become the nominee unless there are extraordinary circumstances. Given the limited time before the Republican National Convention and the entrenched support for leading candidates, it is highly improbable that Will Hurd will secure the nomination.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of October 2023, President Joe Biden has announced his intention to run for re-election in the 2024 U.S. Presidential Election. While there are concerns about his age—he is currently the oldest sitting president—and occasional speculation about his health and cognitive abilities, there have been no official indications that he plans to drop out of the race.

Historically, sitting presidents who seek re-election rarely drop out before the election unless due to significant health issues or major scandals. The last time an incumbent president chose not to run for re-election under pressure was Lyndon B. Johnson in 1968, primarily due to the Vietnam War's unpopularity.

Given that Will Hurd is not selected as the Republican nominee—a highly likely scenario since he is a relatively low-profile candidate with minimal support—the condition is effectively asking about the likelihood of Biden dropping out under normal circumstances.

Taking into account the low probability of severe health issues or unforeseen events compelling President Biden to withdraw before July 20, 2024, the chance of this happening is minimal but not zero.

question.title: Will OpenAI publish a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, OpenAI publishes a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of October 2023, OpenAI has shown a strong commitment to AI safety and transparency. In previous model releases, such as GPT-4, OpenAI engaged external organizations like the Alignment Research Center (ARC) to conduct red-teaming exercises. They publicly shared summaries of these external evaluations in their system cards and technical reports.

The increasing global focus on AI safety, ethical considerations, and regulatory compliance adds pressure on AI developers to be transparent about their safety measures. Publishing a public report with results from external red-teaming would demonstrate OpenAI's dedication to responsible AI development and could help build trust with users, policymakers, and the broader community.

Furthermore, OpenAI is part of industry initiatives advocating for collaborative approaches to AI safety. Given the competitive landscape, there is also an incentive for OpenAI to lead by example and set industry standards.

Potential obstacles, such as concerns over intellectual property, competitive advantage, or the risk of exposing vulnerabilities, can be mitigated by controlling the depth of information disclosed in the report.

Considering these factors, it is likely that OpenAI will publish a public report detailing the results of external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024.

They've engaged with the broader AI community through research publications and discussions on safety practices. The trend in the AI industry is moving towards greater transparency and third-party evaluations, especially concerning safety and ethical considerations. Companies like OpenAI have engaged in external red-teaming and have published reports to foster trust and demonstrate a commitment to safety. Regulatory bodies and public opinion are increasingly advocating for such practices to ensure responsible AI deployment.

Given these factors, it's plausible that Anthropic may undertake external red-teaming of their models and publish a report by June 30, 2024. Their commitment to safety and the industry's trajectory towards transparency support this possibility. However, considerations such as resource allocation, proprietary technology concerns, and strategic priorities might influence their decision.

question.title: Given Anthropic publishes a report with external red-teaming results by June 30, 2024, will OpenAI do the same?

Resolution criteria for the outcome (Q): Resolves YES if, by June 30, 2024, OpenAI publishes a public report with the results from an external party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models. Resolves NO otherwise. If the condition is not met, resolves N/A.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Given that Anthropic publishes a public report detailing external red-teaming results by June 30, 2024, several factors influence the likelihood of OpenAI doing the same: 1. Competitive Pressure and Industry Standards: - Reputation and Trust: If Anthropic demonstrates transparency and a commitment to safety by releasing such a report, OpenAI may feel compelled to match this level of openness to maintain its reputation as a leader in AI safety. - Industry Norms: Anthropic's action could set a new industry standard for transparency in AI safety. OpenAI might follow suit to align with emerging best practices. 2. OpenAI's Historical Practices: - Transparency Efforts: OpenAI has previously published safety guidelines, research papers, and system cards (e.g., for GPT-4) that include safety considerations. - Caution with Disclosures: However, OpenAI has been cautious about releasing detailed technical information, citing concerns over misuse, competitive advantage, and safety risks (e.g., limited technical details on GPT-4). 3. Regulatory and Public Pressure: - Increasing Scrutiny: Governments and the public are increasingly concerned about AI safety. External red-teaming reports could become expected or even mandated. - Proactive Compliance: OpenAI might choose to be proactive in demonstrating compliance with potential future regulations by releasing such reports. 4. Internal Policies and Strategic Decisions: - Resource Allocation: Preparing and publishing a red-teaming report requires significant resources. OpenAI would need to prioritize this among other initiatives. - Risk Assessment: OpenAI may weigh the risks of disclosing vulnerabilities against the benefits of transparency. 5. Collaboration with External Parties: - Existing Partnerships: If OpenAI already collaborates with external safety teams, they might be more inclined to publish the findings. - Security Concerns: They might also be wary of revealing vulnerabilities that could be exploited. Considering these factors, while there is a reasonable likelihood that OpenAI will publish a red-teaming report in response to Anthropic's publication, there is also significant uncertainty due to OpenAI's cautious approach to disclosures.

Given that Anthropic does not publish a public report with results from external red-teaming by June 30, 2024, OpenAI may have additional incentive to showcase their commitment to transparency and safety leadership in the AI industry. question.title: Will Biden remain President through end of July 2024?
question.body:
Resolves YES if Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET); resolves NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then.

Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendement (i.e. making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution. (Acting President is different from President under the Constitution)

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning: Joe Biden is currently the President of the United States and has announced his intention to run for re-election in 2024. The period in question is from now until the end of July 2024, approximately 10 months from now. The main factors that could cause him to cease being president before then are death, resignation, or removal from office.

1. **Death**: President Biden is currently 80 years old (born November 20, 1942) and will turn 81 in November 2023. According to actuarial life tables, the annual mortality rate for someone his age is around 5-6%. However, considering he has access to excellent healthcare and likely receives regular medical evaluations, his risk may be slightly lower than the average for his age group. Over a 10-month period, the risk would be proportionally less, perhaps around 4-5%.

2. **Resignation**: There are currently no significant indications that President Biden intends to resign before the end of July 2024. He has publicly stated his intention to run for a second term. While unforeseen circumstances could always arise (such as health issues or personal reasons), the probability seems low.

3. **Removal from Office**: Removal would require impeachment by the House and conviction by a two-thirds majority in the Senate. Given the current political makeup of Congress, with Democrats holding a slim majority in the Senate, this is highly unlikely.

4. **Temporary Transfer of Power**: As the question specifies, a temporary transfer of power under the 25th Amendment does not affect the resolution.

Considering these factors, the combined probability of any of these events occurring before the end of July 2024 is relatively low. Summing the estimated risks, there might be around a 5-7% chance that he does not remain in office due to death or resignation. Therefore, there is approximately a 93-95% chance that he remains President through the end of July 2024.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning:

Section 3 of the 14th Amendment prohibits individuals who have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States from holding federal office. Following the events of January 6, 2021, there has been discussion among some legal scholars, politicians, and advocacy groups about the applicability of this provision to Donald Trump.

As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, several efforts have been initiated to prevent Donald Trump from appearing on the ballot under this clause:

1. **Legal Actions**: Advocacy groups in certain states have filed lawsuits aiming to disqualify Trump based on Section 3. These cases are in preliminary stages and have not yet resulted in definitive rulings.

2. **Historical Precedence**: Section 3 has rarely been applied since the post-Civil War era. Its modern applicability is untested, and courts may be cautious in setting new precedents without clear legislative guidance.

3. **Judicial Challenges**: Any decision to remove Trump from a state's ballot would likely face immediate appeals, potentially reaching higher courts, including the Supreme Court. The judicial process is time-consuming, and resolutions may not occur before the specified date.

4. **Political Implications**: Election officials and state governments may be hesitant to unilaterally remove a major party candidate due to potential political backlash and the importance of upholding voters' rights to choose their preferred candidate.

5. **Diverse State Responses**: Even if one state were to successfully remove Trump from the ballot, it does not guarantee that other states would follow suit. Each state's legal system and political climate can lead to different outcomes.

Considering these factors, while there is a non-zero possibility that efforts to block Trump from the ballot could succeed in at least one state by July 15, 2024, the overall likelihood remains low due to the legal complexities, time constraints, and potential for appeals delaying final decisions past the resolution date.

question.title: Given Donald Trump is removed or blocked from a primary election ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, will Biden remain President through July 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: On July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. This is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements do not suffice for resolution. The question strictly pertains to whether Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the condition is not met.

Then, is it true that Biden will remain US President through the end of July 2024 (ET)? This resolves YES if Biden remains President through the end of July 2024. It resolves NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then. A temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment (making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a NO resolution, as Acting President is different from President under the Constitution.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Given that as of July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of at least one U.S. state under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, we can consider the potential impacts on President Biden's tenure.

Health Considerations:

- Age: President Biden will be 81 years old in November 2023. Based on actuarial tables, the one-year mortality rate for an 81-year-old male in the United States is approximately 5-6%. Since the period in question is from now until the end of July 2024 (about 10 months), the mortality risk is slightly less, around 4-5%.
  
- Health Status: As of my knowledge cutoff in September 2021, President Biden has not disclosed any severe health issues that would indicate a higher risk than the average for his age group.

Political Stability:

- Resignation: There have been no credible reports suggesting that President Biden intends to resign before the end of his term.
  
- Impeachment and Removal: While the possibility of impeachment exists in a polarized political climate, actual removal from office requires a two-thirds majority in the Senate, making it highly unlikely.
  
- 25th Amendment: A temporary transfer of power under the 25th Amendment does not affect the resolution, as specified.

Impact of Trump's Removal from Ballots:

- Civil Unrest: The removal of Trump from primary ballots could lead to increased political tension and possibly civil unrest. However, while civil unrest can be disruptive, it is unlikely to directly result in the President ceasing to hold office.
  
- Security Risks: Increased tensions could slightly elevate security risks. However, the U.S. Secret Service and other agencies are tasked with protecting the President, and the likelihood of a successful attack is extremely low.

Conclusion:

Taking into account the health-related risks and the low probability of political or security events leading to President Biden leaving office before the end of July 2024, the overall probability that he remains President through that time is high.

question.title: Conditional on Donald Trump not being removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, will Biden remain President through the end of July 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Donald Trump has not been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment as of July 15, 2024. This is confirmed by the lack of official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports indicating such a removal or block.

Then is it true that Biden will remain US President through the end of July 2024 (ET)? This resolves YES if Biden remains President through that time, and NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then. A temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment does not affect this resolution.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of October 2023, President Joe Biden is serving his first term as the President of the United States. Here are the key factors influencing whether he will remain in office through the end of July 2024:

1. **Age and Health:** President Biden was born on November 20, 1942, making him 80 years old as of October 2023. He will turn 81 in November 2023. According to actuarial life tables, the annual mortality rate for an 81-year-old male in the United States is approximately 7%. However, considering that the time frame in question is about 10 months (from October 2023 to the end of July 2024), the mortality risk during this period is slightly lower, around 5% to 6%. Additionally, the President has access to the best medical care, which may reduce health-related risks compared to the general population.

2. **Resignation:** There are no current indications or credible reports suggesting that President Biden intends to resign before the end of July 2024. Historically, presidential resignations are rare, with the only instance being President Nixon's resignation in 1974 amid the Watergate scandal.

3. **Impeachment and Removal from Office:** While impeachment proceedings can be initiated by the House of Representatives, removal from office requires a two-thirds majority vote in the Senate. Given the current political composition of Congress and the lack of substantial bipartisan support for such an action against President Biden, the likelihood of removal through impeachment is very low.

4. **25th Amendment Considerations:** A temporary transfer of power under the 25th Amendment does not affect the resolution of this question. Therefore, any brief periods where Vice President Harris might assume presidential duties temporarily would not impact the outcome.

5. **External Factors:** There are no significant external factors or credible threats that are likely to result in President Biden leaving office before the specified date. Security measures and protocols are robust for the protection of the President.

6. **Conditional Independence:** The condition that Donald Trump has not been removed or blocked from any primary election ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024, does not have a direct causal relationship with President Biden remaining in office. Therefore, the condition does not significantly affect the probability of President Biden's tenure through the end of July 2024.

**Conclusion:**
Considering all these factors, the primary risk to President Biden not remaining in office is age-related health issues, which present a relatively low probability within the given time frame. Other risks such as resignation, impeachment, or incapacity are minimal based on current information.

question.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, the 2024 U.S. Presidential Election is expected to be a competitive race between the incumbent President Joe Biden and former President Donald Trump. Predicting the exact polling numbers for a specific date like July 15, 2024, involves considerable uncertainty due to several factors: 1. Polling Volatility: National polling averages can fluctuate significantly over time due to changing political climates, events, and news cycles. Historical data shows that polls can shift by several percentage points in short periods. 2. Narrow Range Specification: The question asks for Trump's lead to be greater than 2% but less than or equal to 3%. This is a very specific 1-point range. Given the typical margins of error in polling and the variability of public opinion, the probability that the polling difference falls precisely within this narrow window on a specific date is relatively low. 3. Historical Polling Data: In previous election cycles, it's uncommon for the national polling average to remain in such a narrow range for an extended period. Polls often show leads that fluctuate beyond 1-point intervals. 4. Current Political Climate: Factors such as the economy, international events, domestic policies, and both candidates' campaign strategies will influence public opinion over the coming months. Unpredictable events (e.g., economic downturns, scandals, major legislative achievements) could sway the polls significantly in either direction. 5. Statistical Considerations: Assuming a normal distribution of possible polling leads with a standard deviation reflecting historical polling variability, the probability of the lead falling within any specific 1% range on a given day is small. **Conclusion:** While it's possible that Trump could be leading Biden by a margin within that specific range on July 15, 2024, the combination of polling volatility and the narrowness of the specified range makes it unlikely. Therefore, based on the factors above, I estimate the probability to be approximately 10%.

question.title: Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a **Yes** resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, President Joe Biden has officially announced his intention to run for re-election in the 2024 presidential race. While there have been discussions and concerns about his age—he would be 82 at the start of a potential second term—there have been no concrete indications that he plans to step aside.

Historically, incumbent presidents rarely decline their party's nomination unless faced with significant health issues, major personal scandals, or substantial pressure from their party due to poor approval ratings. As of now, President Biden's approval ratings are moderate, and there is no major scandal affecting his presidency. Additionally, there is no clear alternative within the Democratic Party who is positioned to take over the nomination seamlessly.

However, given his age, there is a non-negligible possibility that unforeseen health issues could arise between now and July 15, 2024, which might prompt him to withdraw from the race. There is also the unpredictable nature of politics, where unexpected events could influence such a decision.

Taking all these factors into account—the low likelihood of an incumbent president stepping down, balanced against the higher-than-usual risk due to age-related health concerns—I estimate the probability that Joe Biden will announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President, to be around 10%.

question.title: If Joe Biden announces he will not accept the Democratic nomination before July 15, 2024, will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Joe Biden announces before 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, that he will not seek and will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President in the 2024 cycle. The announcement must be definitive, public, official, unambiguous, and conclusive, leaving no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the nomination.

Then, is it true that Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average, will be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3? This is based on the 538 national polling average for the 2024 presidential election as reported on the chart for July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024. A positive value indicates a Trump lead, while a negative value indicates a Biden lead.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
The question considers the scenario where Joe Biden announces before July 15, 2024, that he will not seek or accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President in the 2024 cycle. This announcement would have significant implications for polling data and voter behavior.

1. **Impact on Polling**:
   - **Shift in Polling Focus**: Once Biden officially withdraws, pollsters are likely to focus on other potential Democratic candidates. Polls matching Donald Trump against Biden may become less frequent or cease altogether.
   - **Validity of Polls Including Biden**: Any polls that continue to include Biden may not accurately reflect voter intentions, as respondents are aware that Biden is no longer a candidate.

2. **Voter Behavior**:
   - **Democratic Voters**: Democratic voters who previously supported Biden would begin considering alternative candidates. In hypothetical matchups against Biden, their support for him would likely decrease, knowing he is not running.
   - **Republican Voters**: Trump's support among Republican voters would remain relatively stable.

3. **Expected Polling Outcomes**:
   - **Increased Lead for Trump**: Given that Biden is not a candidate, Trump's lead over Biden in any residual polling could widen significantly beyond typical margins, as Democratic support for Biden diminishes.
   - **Possibility of Limited Data**: With fewer polls including Biden, the data available for the 538 national polling average may be limited or outdated, potentially affecting the reported lead margins.

4. **Probability of Specific Margin**:
   - **Greater than 2% and ≤ 3%**: This is a narrow margin range. Given the circumstances, it's improbable that Trump's lead over Biden would fall precisely within this range.
   - **Likelihood of Larger Margin**: It is more plausible that Trump's lead would exceed 3%, due to decreased support for a non-candidate.

5. **Uncertainties**:
   - **Polling Methodologies**: Different polling organizations may handle Biden's withdrawal differently, introducing variability.
   - **Public Perception**: If there is confusion or skepticism about Biden's announcement, some voters might still express support for him, slightly increasing his polling numbers.

Conclusion:

Considering the factors above, the probability that Trump's lead over Biden will be greater than 2% and less than or equal to 3% on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average, is low. It is more likely that the lead would either be less than or equal to 2% due to anomalous data or exceed 3% due to the loss of Democratic support for Biden.

question.title: If Joe Biden does not announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination, will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Joe Biden does not announce before 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President. This means there is no definitive, public, official announcement from Biden or his campaign indicating that he will not seek and will not accept the nomination for another term as President in the 2024 cycle.

Given this scenario, will Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average? This question will resolve based on the value reported on 538's national polling average chart for the date of July 15, 2024, accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024. A positive value indicates a Trump lead, while a negative value indicates a Biden lead. For example, a value of 2.4 means Trump is 2.4 points ahead of Biden.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of October 2023, the race between Joe Biden and Donald Trump for the 2024 U.S. Presidential Election is expected to be competitive. National polls often show fluctuations based on current events, campaign developments, economic indicators, and international affairs.

Given that Joe Biden does not announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination, he remains the presumptive Democratic nominee. Donald Trump, assuming he secures the Republican nomination, will continue to be his opponent.

The specific question asks about the probability that, on July 15, 2024, Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden will be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 percentage points according to FiveThirtyEight's national polling average.

Several factors influence this probability:

1. Historical Polling Volatility: Polling averages can change significantly over short periods due to news events, debates, policy announcements, and unforeseen incidents. The likelihood that the polling difference falls within a precise 1-point range on a specific date is relatively low.

2. Margin of Error: Polls have a margin of error, typically around ±3%. This means small leads can be statistically insignificant, and slight changes may not reflect true shifts in public opinion.

3. Current Polling Trends: If current polls (as of October 2023) show a tight race with leads oscillating between the candidates within a few percentage points, it's possible but not highly probable that Trump's lead would specifically be between 2% and 3% on July 15, 2024.

4. Potential Influencing Events: Upcoming events such as the primaries, debates, economic changes, or international incidents could sway public opinion in favor of either candidate, making precise predictions challenging.

5. Statistical Likelihood: Given the continuous nature of polling data and the range of possible leads (from a strong Biden lead to a strong Trump lead), the chance that the lead falls within any specific 1-point range is small.

question.title: Will Liz Cheney be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Liz Cheney is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of October 2023, Liz Cheney has not declared her candidacy for the Republican nomination for the 2024 US Presidential Election. She is a former U.S. Representative from Wyoming and has been a vocal critic of former President Donald Trump. After losing her seat in the 2022 Republican primary, Cheney has focused on opposing Trump's influence within the Republican Party.

The Republican primary race is well underway, with several prominent candidates actively campaigning, including Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis, Nikki Haley, and others. These candidates have established significant fundraising efforts, campaign infrastructures, and voter support. Liz Cheney has not participated in any debates, primaries, or campaigning activities associated with seeking the nomination.

Given the advanced stage of the nomination process, the strong positions of existing candidates, and Cheney's lack of any indications that she intends to run, the probability of her being selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee is extremely low.

question.body: This question will resolve as Yes if credible sources report that a person representing the Republican Party has won the special election for OH's 6th district. If popular sources are in disagreement, an Ohio State source or statement will be used. If no election is held before January 1, 2025, the question is annulled.

Bill Johnson, a Republican, currently holds the seat and is expected to serve until the end of his term in January 2025. A special election would only occur if he vacates his seat prematurely due to resignation, passing away, or being appointed to another position, which is unlikely based on available information. Therefore, the probability of a special election happening before January 1, 2025, is low. However, if a special election were to occur, Ohio's 6th district is a historically Republican stronghold, and it is highly likely that the Republican Party would retain the seat. Taking into account the low probability of a special election occurring and the high probability of the Republicans winning if it does, I estimate the overall likelihood of the Republican Party retaining the seat in a special election before the specified date to be low.

question.title: Given the Republican Party loses Ohio's 6th congressional district in the 2024 special election, will Liz Cheney be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question examines the potential impact of the Republican Party losing Ohio's 6th congressional district on Liz Cheney's chances of becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election.

Suppose the following is true: The Republican Party loses Ohio's 6th congressional district (previously held by Bill Johnson) in the 2024 special election. This question will resolve as Yes if credible sources report that a person not representing the Republican Party has won the special election for OH's 6th district. If popular sources are in disagreement, an Ohio State source or statement will be used. If no election is held before January 1, 2025, the question is annulled.

Then, will Liz Cheney be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election? This question will resolve as **Yes** if Liz Cheney is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
1. **Background on Ohio's 6th Congressional District:**
   - Ohio's 6th congressional district has been a reliably Republican seat. Bill Johnson, a Republican, has held this seat since 2011.
   - A loss in this district would be significant and could indicate a shift in voter sentiment or dissatisfaction with the Republican Party's current direction.

2. **Impact of Losing the Seat:**
   - Losing a traditionally safe Republican seat could prompt the party to reassess its strategy and candidate selection.
   - It might lead to discussions about the party's alignment with certain figures or policies that are causing voter attrition.

3. **Liz Cheney's Position within the Republican Party:**
   - Liz Cheney has been a prominent critic of former President Donald Trump, particularly regarding his actions surrounding the January 6th Capitol riot.
   - Her stance led to her being removed from her position as Chair of the House Republican Conference in 2021.
   - In 2022, she lost her Wyoming primary to a Trump-endorsed candidate, indicating diminished support within the party's base.

4. **Likelihood of Becoming the Nominee:**
   - The Republican Party currently has a strong pro-Trump faction. Trump's influence remains substantial among the party's base and leadership as of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023.
   - Other potential candidates like Ron DeSantis have gained popularity and are seen as more likely alternatives to Trump.
   - Liz Cheney's opposition to Trump has alienated her from much of the party's core supporters.

5. **Effect of the Special Election Loss:**
   - While losing Ohio's 6th district would be a notable event, it's uncertain whether it would be sufficient to shift the overall momentum within the party toward Liz Cheney.
   - The loss might spark internal debates but overturning the prevailing pro-Trump sentiment would require more extensive changes.

6. **Delegate Selection and Convention Dynamics:**
   - The Republican nominee is selected by delegates at the National Convention.
   - Delegates are often committed to candidates based on primary and caucus results, reflecting the preferences of the party's voters.
   - Unless there is a significant and widespread shift in voter sentiment reflected across multiple states, it's unlikely that delegates would consolidate around Cheney.

**Conclusion:**
Given her strained relationship with the party's base and leadership, and the strong influence of other candidates, the probability of Liz Cheney becoming the Republican nominee—even after a significant event like losing Ohio's 6th district—is very low.

question.title: Given a member of the Trump family is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024, will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: A member of the Trump family, such as Donald Trump, Donald Trump Jr., Eric Trump, Ivanka Trump, Tiffany Trump, Melania Trump, or Barron Trump, is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024. Given this scenario, will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolution criteria for the condition (P): Resolves Yes if one of the specified members of the Trump family is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024.

Resolution criteria for the outcome (Q): Resolves Yes if before 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement that he will not seek and will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President in the 2024 cycle. The statement must be unambiguous and conclusive. If not made by the deadline, resolves No.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Given that a member of the Trump family is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024, we need to evaluate whether Joe Biden would announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination. As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, President Joe Biden has declared his intention to run for re-election in 2024. He is the incumbent president with substantial support from the Democratic Party establishment. Facing a Trump family member as the Republican nominee, especially Donald Trump whom he defeated in the 2020 election, may reinforce his decision to continue his campaign rather than deter it. Potential reasons that could lead Biden to withdraw include serious health issues, significant personal or political scandals, or considerable pressure from within his party to step aside in favor of a stronger candidate. However, there have been no definitive indicators of such developments occurring. Given these factors, it is unlikely that Biden would announce that he will not accept the nomination before July 15, 2024, even if a Trump family member is his opponent.

question.title: If no Trump family member is the Republican nominee, will Joe Biden announce he won't accept the Democratic nomination before July 15, 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: No member of the Trump family is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024. This includes Donald Trump, Donald Trump Jr., Eric Trump, Ivanka Trump, Tiffany Trump, Melania Trump, and Barron Trump. 

Given this condition, will Joe Biden announce before 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, that he will not seek and will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolution criteria for the outcome: Resolves Yes if Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement before July 15, 2024, stating he will not accept the Democratic nomination for President in the 2024 cycle. The statement must be unambiguous and conclusive. Resolves No if such a statement is not made by the specified time.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, President Joe Biden has officially declared his intention to seek re-election in the 2024 presidential race. He announced his candidacy in April 2023 and has been actively campaigning since then. Although there have been concerns about his age and approval ratings, there are no strong indications that he plans to withdraw from the race.

The condition specifies that no member of the Trump family is the Republican nominee. Assuming this is the case, the Republican nominee is likely to be another prominent figure within the party, such as Ron DeSantis, Nikki Haley, or another contender. The absence of a Trump family member as the nominee might slightly alter the dynamics of the race but is unlikely to be a decisive factor in Biden's decision to continue his campaign.

Incumbent presidents typically run for a second term unless there are compelling reasons not to, such as health issues, significant political pressure, or personal considerations. So far, none of these factors have publicly emerged to suggest that Biden would step down.

Furthermore, withdrawing from the race before mid-July 2024 would place the Democratic Party in a difficult position to nominate and support an alternative candidate with sufficient time to build a robust campaign infrastructure.

question.title: Will 538 Project Biden as the favorite on Friday?
question.body:
This market will resolve to “Yes” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. This market will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50.

The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market.

This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. This market may not resolve until the July 20 datapoints are available. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19.

Please note the resolution refers to the odds of each candidate winning as a number out of 100 reported to the 1 digit mark (eg. "Trump 57 times out of 100"). The listed number of simulations out of 1,000 won by each candidate will NOT be considered.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, the 2024 U.S. presidential election is expected to feature President Joe Biden as the Democratic nominee and former President Donald Trump as the Republican nominee. Both candidates have significant name recognition and established voter bases.

Historically, incumbents have an advantage in presidential elections due to their visibility and the power of the office. President Biden's administration has focused on economic recovery, infrastructure investments, and addressing the COVID-19 pandemic. However, challenges such as inflation, foreign policy issues, or unforeseen events could impact his approval ratings.

Donald Trump remains a polarizing figure. While he maintains strong support within a segment of the Republican base, he also faces legal challenges and controversies that could affect his electability in the general electorate.

FiveThirtyEight's projections are based on a combination of polling data, economic indicators, and other factors. By July 19, 2024, we can expect that primary elections will have concluded, and general election campaigns will be in full swing. Polling at that time will reflect voters' sentiments leading up to the election.

Given the incumbency advantage, the potential for economic recovery, and assuming no significant decline in President Biden's approval ratings, it is reasonable to anticipate that FiveThirtyEight might project Biden as the favorite over Trump on that date. However, the political landscape can change rapidly due to events such as economic fluctuations, international conflicts, or domestic issues.

Considering these factors, I estimate there is a moderate likelihood that FiveThirtyEight will project Biden as the favorite on July 19, 2024.

metadata.chain_of_thought:

The resolution source is FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for July 19. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, this resolves according to the nearest previous figures to July 19.

metadata.chain_of_thought: If Kamala Harris is announcing a running mate before August 7th, it strongly implies that she is the Democratic nominee for president in the 2024 election. In this scenario, Joe Biden would not be running for re-election. Since FiveThirtyEight's election forecast projects probabilities based on the actual candidates running, they would not project Joe Biden as the favorite if he is not a candidate. Therefore, given that Kamala Harris is the nominee and Joe Biden is not running, the probability that FiveThirtyEight projects Joe Biden as the favorite to win the presidential election on July 19, 2024, is effectively zero.

question.title: Given Lithuania fails to qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, will Greece qualify?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Lithuania does not participate in a Semi-final or is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as not having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. Then, will Greece qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024? 

Resolution criteria: 
- Lithuania failing to qualify resolves as Yes if Lithuania does not participate in a Semi-final or is officially announced by the EBU as not having qualified for the Grand Final.
- Greece qualifying resolves as Yes if Greece participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the EBU as having qualified for the Grand Final.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To estimate the probability that Greece will qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, given that Lithuania fails to qualify, we need to consider several factors:

1. **Historical Performance**:
   - **Greece** has had a strong track record in the Eurovision Song Contest. Between 2004 and 2019, Greece qualified for the Grand Final every year except for 2016. However, in recent years (as of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023), Greece's performance has been mixed, with occasional non-qualifications.
   - **Lithuania** has also had variable success, but Lithuania's failure to qualify does not have a direct impact on Greece's chances unless they are in the same semi-final.

2. **Semi-final Allocation**:
   - If Greece and Lithuania are in the same semi-final, Lithuania's failure to qualify means there is one less competitor for the ten spots available, slightly improving the odds for the remaining countries, including Greece.
   - If they are in different semi-finals, Lithuania's performance does not affect Greece's chances.

3. **Voting Patterns**:
   - Neighboring countries and diaspora communities can influence voting patterns. Greece often receives support from countries like Cyprus. Lithuania's absence may have a minimal impact on the overall voting dynamics affecting Greece.

4. **Song Quality and Staging**:
   - The primary factors determining qualification are the song's appeal, the quality of the performance, and the staging.
   - As of October 2023, there is no information about Greece's or Lithuania's entries for Eurovision 2024. Without details on the song and performance, it's challenging to make a precise prediction.

5. **External Factors**:
   - Public opinion, political climate, and the competitiveness of other entries can also influence the results.
   - The absence of Lithuania might marginally improve Greece's chances if they compete in the same semi-final, but the effect is likely minimal.

**Conclusion**:

Given Greece's historical tendency to qualify and assuming they present a strong entry, the probability of Greece qualifying for the Grand Final remains fairly high. Lithuania's failure to qualify might slightly increase Greece's chances if they are in the same semi-final due to less competition. However, without specific information about the entries, any estimate must be taken with caution.

This has precedent; for example, President George W. Bush temporarily transferred power during medical procedures. Estimating the probability of this happening before the specified date is around 10%. question.title: Will Portugal qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?

metadata.chain_of_thought:

- **2019**: Portugal did not qualify for the Grand Final. 
- **2020**: The contest was canceled due to the COVID-19 pandemic. 
- **2021**: Portugal qualified for the Grand Final with The Black Mamba's 'Love Is on My Side,' finishing 12th overall. 
- **2022**: They again qualified with MARO's 'Saudade, Saudade,' achieving a respectable 9th place. 
- **2023**: Although I don't have specific details about the 2023 contest outcomes due to my knowledge cutoff, the trend suggests continued participation and potential qualification. 

Portugal's recent track record indicates an upward trajectory in terms of both qualification and final placements. Their entries have been well-received for originality and authenticity, resonating with both juries and the public vote.

question.title: At the Paris Summer Olympics in 2024, will the men's 100m dash winning time break the Olympic record of 9.63s?

Recent top performers like Christian Coleman, Trayvon Bromell, and Ferdinand Omanyala have personal bests in the 9.76 to 9.77-second range. At the 2021 Tokyo Olympics, the winning time was 9.80 seconds by Lamont Marcell Jacobs. No athlete in the past decade has broken the 9.70-second barrier. Breaking the Olympic record would require an athlete to deliver a historically exceptional performance, possibly setting a new personal best significantly faster than their previous times. While incremental improvements are possible, shaving off more than 0.13 seconds at this elite level is highly unlikely. Environmental factors like perfect weather conditions and track technology could contribute, but they are unlikely to account for the necessary improvement alone. Given the data and trends in men's sprinting, the probability of someone running the 100m dash in less than 9.63 seconds at the 2024 Paris Olympics is low.

question.title: Will a swimmer win the most gold medals at the 2024 Paris Olympics?
question.body: The question resolves as **Yes** if the athlete with the highest number of 2024 Olympic gold medals competes in the swimming events.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Swimmers have historically been the athletes most likely to win multiple gold medals at a single Olympic Games due to the high number of events they can participate in. For instance, Michael Phelps won eight gold medals in the 2008 Beijing Olympics and continued to win multiple golds in subsequent games. In the 2020 Tokyo Olympics (held in 2021), swimmer Caeleb Dressel won five gold medals. Other sports, such as gymnastics and athletics, also offer opportunities for multiple medals but typically not as many as swimming. Gymnasts like Simone Biles have won multiple golds, but the maximum number of events is fewer compared to swimming. Given the structure of Olympic events and past trends, it's highly likely that a swimmer will win the most gold medals at the 2024 Paris Olympics. There are emerging swimmers who are strong contenders for multiple events, and the nature of swimming allows for participation in both individual and relay events, increasing the chances of winning multiple gold medals.
